fractalnetworks package¶

Submodules¶

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality module¶

This module contains functions to analyse the betweenness centralities of nodes and edges in fractal networks.

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.analyse_betweenness_centrality(G, bcs=None)[source]¶

Returns key attributes of the betweenness centrality distribution of a network. Finds the maximum, minimum and mean betweenness centrality. Also calculates the standard deviation and number of outliers with greater than expected betweenness centrality.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • bcs (list, optional) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

Returns:

Tuple containing a float, float, float, float, int and float, in order:

the maximum betweenness centrality in the network; the minimum betweenness centrality in the network; the mean betweenness centrality in the network; the standard deviation of the betweenness centrality distribution in the network; number of nodes with significantly higher betweenness centrality than expected; the mean betweenness centrality of the top 10% of nodes in the network.

Return type:

(tuple)

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.calc_betweenness_degree_correlation(G, bcs=None, degrees=None)[source]¶

Calculates the Pearson correlation coefficient for the degree and betweenness centrality of the nodes in a network. Fractal networks are hypothesised to be less correlated in this regard than non-fractal networks.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • bcs (list, optional) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the betweenness distribution is calculated.

  • degrees (list, optional) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the degree distribution is calculated

Returns:

Pearson’s correlation coefficient of the degree and betweenness centrality distributions.

Return type:

(float)

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.calc_betweenness_degree_correlation_hubs(G, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, bcs=None, degrees=None)[source]¶

Calculates the Pearson correlation coefficient for the degree and betweenness centrality of the hubs in a network.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • hubs (list, optional) – A list of nodes indexes for hubs in the network. If no list is passed, hubs are found using the hub_method.

  • hub_method (function, optional) – The method by which to calculate hubs, if hubs are not given. Default is identify_hubs.

  • bcs (list, optional) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

  • degrees (list, optional) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the degree distribution is calculated.

Returns:

Pearson’s correlation coefficient of the degree and betweenness centrality distributions.

Return type:

(float)

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.calc_betweenness_degree_correlation_non_hubs(G, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, bcs=None, degrees=None)[source]¶

Calculates the Pearson correlation coefficient for the degree and betweenness centrality of non-hub nodes.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • hubs (list, optional) – A list of nodes indexes for hubs in the network. If no list is passed, hubs are found using the hub_method.

  • hub_method (function) – The method by which to calculate hubs, if hubs are not given. Default is identify_hubs.

  • bcs (list, optional) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the betweenness distribution is calculated.

  • degrees (list, optional) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the degree distribution is calculated.

Returns:

Pearson’s correlation coefficient of the degree and betweenness centrality distributions.

Return type:

(float)

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.edge_betweenness_degree_correlation(G, degrees=None, ebcs=None)[source]¶

Calculates the correlation between the betweenness centrality of edges and the degree of its endpoints.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • degrees (list, optional) – A list of node degrees in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

  • ebcs (list, optional) – A list of edge betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

Returns:

Pearson’s correlation coefficient of the endpoint degree and edge betweenness centrality distributions.

Return type:

(float)

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.edge_vertex_betweenness_correlation(G, bcs=None, ebcs=None)[source]¶
Calculates the correlation between the betweenness centrality of edges and the betweenness centrality of its

endpoints.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • bcs (list, optional) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

  • ebcs (list, optional) – A list of edge betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

Returns:

Pearson’s correlation coefficient of the endpoint and edge betweenness centrality distributions.

Return type:

(float)

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.find_betweenness_centralities(G)[source]¶

Calculates the normalised betweenness centrality distribution of the network.

Parameters:

G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

Returns:

A list of betweenness centralities in the network.

The i-th value is the betweenness centrality of the i-th node.

Return type:

(list)

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.find_edge_betweenness_centralities(G)[source]¶

Calculates the normalised edge betweenness centrality distribution of the network.

Parameters:

G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

Returns:

A list of edge betweenness centralities in the network.

The i-th value is the betweenness centrality of the i-th edge.

Return type:

(list)

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.find_hub_betweenness(G, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, bcs=None)[source]¶

Finds lists of betweenness centralities for the hub and non-hub nodes in the network.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • hubs (list, optional) – A list of hubs in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the hubs are found using hub_method.

  • hub_method (function, optional) – Specifies the method used to calculate hubs if hubs are not given. Default is identify_hubs.

  • bcs (list, optional) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

Returns:

Tuple containing two lists.

The first is a list of betweenness centralities of hubs. The second is a list of betweenness centralities of non-hubs.

Return type:

(tuple)

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.hub_hub_path_betweenness(G, bcs=None, degrees=None, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, hub_hub_path_nodes=None)[source]¶

Analyses the betweenness of nodes on the paths between hubs. Returns a list of the betweenness centralities of these nodes.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • bcs (list, optional) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

  • degrees (list, optional) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

  • hubs (list, optional) – A list of hubs in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the function finds the hubs.

  • hub_method (function, optional) – Specifies the method used to calculate hubs if hubs are not given. Default is identify_hubs.

  • hub_hub_path_nodes (list, optional) – A list of nodes on the paths between hubs. If None given the function calculates them.

Returns:

A list of betweenness centralities belonging to nodes found on the paths between hubs.

Return type:

(list)

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.hub_hub_path_betweenness_by_occurrence(G, bcs=None, degrees=None, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, hub_hub_path_nodes=None, occurrences=None)[source]¶

Analyses the betweenness of nodes on the paths between hubs with the number of their occurrences. Returns a list of the betweenness centralities of these nodes,

and the Pearson correlation coefficient between the number of occurrences on such a path and their centrality.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • bcs (list, optional) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

  • degrees (list, optional) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

  • hubs (list, optional) – A list of hubs in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the function finds the hubs.

  • hub_method (function, optional) – Specifies the method used to calculate hubs if hubs are not given. Default is identify_hubs.

  • hub_hub_path_nodes (list, optional) – A list of nodes on the paths between hubs. If None given the function calculates them.

  • occurrences (dict, optional) – A dictionary of hub path nodes and their number of occurrences. If None given the function calculated them.

Returns:

Tuple containing a list and a float.

The list is alist of betweenness centralities belonging to nodes found on the paths between hubs. The float is the Pearson’s correlation coefficient of the betweenness centrality and number of occurrences on paths sbetween hubs of nodes.

Return type:

(tuple)

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.plot_betweenness_centralities(G, bcs=None, save_path=None, plot=True)[source]¶

Plots the betweenness centrality distribution of a given network on a histogram.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • bcs (list, optional) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

  • save_path (str, optional) – If a save path is given then the histogram is saved as a .png file. Default is None.

  • plot (bool, optional) – If True, a histogram of the betweenness centrality distribution is displayed. Default is True.

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.plot_degree_distribution(G, degrees=None, save_path=None, plot=True)[source]¶

Plots the degree distribution of a given network on a histogram.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • degrees (list, optional) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

  • save_path (str, optional) – If a save path is given then the histogram is saved as a .png file. Default is None.

  • plot (bool, optional) – If True, a histogram of the degree distribution is displayed. Default is True.

fractalnetworks.boxrenormalisation module¶

This module contains the code to renormalise a network using a box covering

fractalnetworks.boxrenormalisation.assign_nodes_to_boxes(G, centres, central_distance)[source]¶

Generates a dictionary assigning each node to a box under the MEMB algorithm.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • centres (list) – A list of centre nodes according to the MEMB algorithm.

  • central_distance (dict) – A dictionary containing nodes as keys and their central distance as values.

Returns:

A dictionary containing nodes as keys and the box they are assigned to as the value.

Return type:

(dict)

fractalnetworks.boxrenormalisation.find_boxes(nodes_to_boxes, centres)[source]¶

Finds a list of nodes assigned to each box in a network.

Parameters:

  • nodes_to_boxes (dict) – A dictionary with nodes as keys and their corresponding boxes as values.

  • centres (list) – A list of the nodes found as centres under the MEMB algorithm.

Returns:

A dictionary with boxes as keys and a list of nodes in that box as the value.

Return type:

(dict)

fractalnetworks.boxrenormalisation.find_boxes_and_renormalise_iteration(G, lB, iter_count=1, filepath='graph', method=<function accelerated_MEMB>, draw=False)[source]¶

Performs one iteration of box covering and renormalisation. Stores all results in new files.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • lB (int) – The diameter of the boxes for the box covering.

  • iter_count (int, optional) – The current iteration number. Default is 1 if no value is given.

  • filepath (str, optional) – The path to which the box-covered and renormalised graphs will be saved. Default is “graph”.

  • method (function, optional) – The MEMB method used to find the box covering. Default is degree_based_MEMB.

  • draw (bool, optional) – If True then display the networks. Default is False.

Returns:

The network after box renormalisation.

Return type:

(igraph.Graph)

fractalnetworks.boxrenormalisation.find_central_distance(G, centres)[source]¶

Finds the central distance for each node in a network given a list of centres.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • centres (list) – A list of centre nodes from the MEMB algorithm.

Returns:

A dictionary containing nodes as keys and their central distance as values.

Return type:

(dict)

fractalnetworks.boxrenormalisation.renormalise_graph(G, boxes, nodes_to_boxes, draw=False)[source]¶

Renormalise a graph under a given box-covering.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • boxes (dict) – A dictionary with boxes as keys and a list of nodes in that box as the value.

  • nodes_to_boxes (dict) – A dictionary with nodes as keys and their corresponding boxes as values.

  • draw (bool, optional) – If True then displays the renormalised graph. Default is False.

Returns:

The network after renormalisation.

Return type:

(igraph.Graph)

fractalnetworks.boxrenormalisation.renormalise_iteratively(filepath, lB, method=<function accelerated_MEMB>, draw=False)[source]¶

Iteratively finds the box covering and then renormalises the network until only one node is left.

Parameters:

  • filepath (str) – The filepath to the network file.

  • lB (int) – The diameter of the boxes for the box covering.

  • method (function, optional) – The MEMB method used to find the box covering. Default is degree_based_MEMB.

  • draw (bool, optional) – If True then display the networks. Default is False.

fractalnetworks.determiningfractality module¶

This module contains the functions needed to determine if a given network is fractal or non-fractal

fractalnetworks.determiningfractality.calculate_lB_NB_dist(G, diam=None, normalise=False, lB_min=2, save_path=None, colouring_ordering_method=None)[source]¶

Finds the distribution of the optimal number of boxes NB against the diameter of these boxes lB.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • diam (int, optional) – The diameter of the network G. If none given, the diameter is calculated. Default is None.

  • normalise (bool, optional) –

    If True, normalises the number of boxes over the total

    number of nodes in the network.

    Default is False.

  • lB_min (int, optional) – The minimum value of lB used to cover the network. Default is 2.

  • save_path (str, optional) – The filepath to save the results to. If none given, results are not saved. Default is None.

  • colouring_ordering_method (function, optional) –

    The method by which to order the nodes for the greedy

    colouring algorithm.

    If none given, nodes are ordered lexicographically. Default is None.

Returns:

List of values for the box diameters lB. (list): List of the corresponding optimal number of boxes NB.

Return type:

(list)

fractalnetworks.determiningfractality.find_best_range(x, y, percentage=1.0)[source]¶
Finds the portion of the distribution which covers percentage% of the total distribution which best fits a linear

distribution.

Parameters:

  • x (list) – A list of values of x

  • y (list) – A list of values of y

  • percentage (float, optional) – The percentage of the distribution to test. Default is 1.0

Returns:

Tuple containing 3 floats.

The first is the optimal value of the intercept A. The second is the optimal value of the gradient c=dB, which is the fractal dimension. The third is the coefficient of determination of the linear fit with parameters A and c.

Return type:

(tuple)

fractalnetworks.determiningfractality.find_fractal_dimension(loglB, logNB, p_list=None)[source]¶

Finds the fractal dimension of a fractal network given the log(lB)-log(NB) distribution. Fits a linear distribution of the form log(NB) = clog(lB) + A, where c is the fractal dimension dB.

Parameters:

  • loglB (list) – A list of values of log(lB)

  • logNB (list) – A list of values of log(NB)

  • p_list (list, optional) –

    A list of percentages p. The fractal dimension is given by the gradient of the best fit over p% of the

    distribution.

    Default is None.

Returns:

The optimal value of the intercept A. float : The optimal value of the gradient c=dB, which is the fractal dimension. float : The coefficient of determination of the linear fit with parameters A and c.

Return type:

float

fractalnetworks.determiningfractality.is_fractal(results_filepath, plot=False, verbose=False, save_path=None, p_list=None)[source]¶

Tests if a given lB-NB distribution is a power-law or exponential, thus determining if a network is fractal or not.

Parameters:

  • results_filepath (str) – The filepath for the csv file storing the lB-NB distribution.

  • plot (bool, optional) – If True, a comparison of the relationship between lB and NB is plotted.

  • verbose (bool, optional) – If True, the results are printed.

  • save_path (str, optional) – The figure generated is saved to the file path, if given. Default is None.

  • p_list (list, optional) –

    A list of percentages p. The fractal dimension is given by the gradient of the best fit over p% of the

    distribution.

    Default is None.

Returns:

True if the network is fractal, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

fractalnetworks.greedyalgorithm module¶

Implements the greedy colouring box covering algorithm

fractalnetworks.greedyalgorithm.greedy_box_covering(G, lB, node_order=None)[source]¶

Colours the network in boxes of diameter lB using the greedy algorithm (Song, Gallos, et al., 2007).

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • lB (int) – The diameter of the boxes for the box covering.

  • node_order (list, optional) – The order of the nodes in which the greedy colouring is applied. If None, the nodes are coloured in lexicographical order. Default is None.

Returns:

Tuple containing a dict and int.

The dict represents the greedy colouring, with the nodes as keys and the colours as values. The int is the number of boxes of diameter lB needed to cover the network.

Return type:

(tuple)

fractalnetworks.greedyalgorithm.greedy_colouring(G, node_order=None)[source]¶

Colour a graph by the greedy colouring algorithm (Song, Gallos, et al., 2007).

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The graph to be analysed.

  • node_order (list, optional) – The order of the nodes in which the greedy colouring is applied. If None, the nodes are coloured in lexicographical order. Default is None.

Returns:

A dictionary with nodes as keys and the colours they are assigned as values.

Return type:

(dict)

fractalnetworks.greedyalgorithm.make_dual_graph(graph, lB)[source]¶

Finds the dual graph as defined under the greedy colouring algorithm (Song, Gallos, et al., 2007). In the dual graph, two nodes are connected if the distance between them is at least lB.

Parameters:

  • graph (igraph.Graph) – The graph to be analysed.

  • lB (int) – The diameter of the boxes for the box covering.

Returns:

The dual graph.

Return type:

(igraph.Graph)

fractalnetworks.greedyalgorithm.smallest_last(G)[source]¶

Orders nodes using the smallest last (Matula and Beck, 1983) method.

Parameters:

G (igraph.Graph) – The network being ordered.

Returns:

A list of the nodes in order.

Return type:

(list)

fractalnetworks.hubrepulsion module¶

This file contains function to analyse the effect of hub-hub repulsion in fractal networks.

fractalnetworks.hubrepulsion.calculate_HCS(G, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, degrees=None, normalise_by_number_of_hubs=False, normalise_by_mean_hub_degree=False, normalise_by_mean_degree=False, normalise_by_number_of_edges=False)[source]¶

Calculate the Hub Connectivity Score (HCS) of the network. This is the average number of hubs each hub is adjacent to (Zakar-Polyák, Nagy, and Molontay, 2022).

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • hubs (list, optional) – A list of hubs in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the function finds the hubs.

  • hub_method (function, optional) – Specifies the method used to find hubs. Default is identify_hubs.

  • degrees (list, optional) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

  • normalise_by_number_of_hubs (bool, optional) – If True, normalises the HCS by the number of hubs. Default is False.

  • normalise_by_mean_hub_degree (bool, optional) – If True, normalises the HCS by the mean hub degree. Default is False.

  • normalise_by_mean_degree (bool, optional) – If True, normalises the HCS by the mean degree. Default is False.

  • normalise_by_number_of_edges (bool, optional) – If True, normalises the HCS by the number of edges. Default is False.

Returns:

The Hub Connectivity Score of the network.

Return type:

(float)

fractalnetworks.hubrepulsion.find_degree_distribution(G)[source]¶

Calculates the degree distribution of the network.

Returns:

A list of degrees in the network. The i-th value is the degree of the i-th node.

Return type:

(list)

fractalnetworks.hubrepulsion.find_hub_hub_edges(G, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, degrees=None)[source]¶

Finds the number of edges in a network which connect hubs to other hubs.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • hubs (list, optional) – A list of hubs in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the function finds the hubs.

  • hub_method (function, optional) – Specifies the method used to find hubs. Default is identify_hubs.

  • degrees (list, optional) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

Returns:

The number of edges between hubs.

Return type:

(int)

fractalnetworks.hubrepulsion.find_hub_hub_path_edges(G, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>)[source]¶

Finds the edges on the shortest paths between pairs of hubs.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • hubs (list, optional) – A list of hubs in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function finds the hubs.

  • hub_method (func, optional) – Specifies the method used to find hubs. Default is identify_hubs.

Returns:

A list of edges on the paths between hubs.

Return type:

(list)

fractalnetworks.hubrepulsion.find_hub_hub_path_node_occurrences(G, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, degrees=None)[source]¶

Finds the nodes on the shortest paths between pairs of hubs, and the number of times they appear.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • hubs (list, optional) – A list of hubs in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the function finds the hubs.

  • hub_method (function, optional) – Specifies the method used to find hubs. Default is identify_hubs.

  • degrees (list, optional) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

Returns:

Tuple containing a list and dict, specifically:

a list of nodes on the paths between hubs; and a dictionary with nodes as keys and the number of times they appear on shortest paths as values.

Return type:

(tuple)

fractalnetworks.hubrepulsion.find_hub_hub_path_nodes(G, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, degrees=None)[source]¶

Finds the nodes on the shortest paths between pairs of hubs in the network.

Args: G (igraph.Graph) : The network to be analysed. hubs (list, optional) : A list of hubs in the network.

If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the function finds the hubs.

hub_method (function, optional)Specifies the method used to find hubs.

Default is identify_hubs.

degrees (list, optional)A list of degrees in the network.

If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

Returns:

A list of nodes on the paths between hubs.

Return type:

(list)

fractalnetworks.hubrepulsion.identify_hubs(G, degrees=None)[source]¶

Identify the hubs of the network using the Z-score, where hubs are those nodes with Z > 3.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • degrees (list, optional) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

Returns:

A list of nodes with Z > 3.

Return type:

(list)

fractalnetworks.hubrepulsion.identify_hubs_by_mean(G, degrees=None, factor=2)[source]¶
Identify the hubs of the network using the mean, where hubs are those nodes with degree greater than some factor

(usually 2) times the mean.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • degrees (list, optional) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

  • factor (int, optional) – The factor by which the mean is multiplied to identify hubs. Default is 2.

Returns:

A list of hubs.

Return type:

(list)

fractalnetworks.hubrepulsion.identify_hubs_by_percentile(G, degrees=None, percentile=90)[source]¶

Identify the hubs of the network by percentile, where hubs are those in some percentile of the degree distribution.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • degrees (list, optional) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

  • percentile (int, optional) – The percentile hubs belong to. Default is 90.

Returns:

A list of hubs.

Return type:

(list)

fractalnetworks.hubrepulsion.mean_hub_degree(G, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, degrees=None)[source]¶

Calculates the mean hub degree in the network.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • hubs (list, optional) – A list of hubs in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the function finds the hubs.

  • hub_method (function, optional) – Specifies the method used to find hubs. Default is identify_hubs.

  • degrees (list, optional) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

Returns:

The mean degree of hubs in the network.

Return type:

(float)

fractalnetworks.maximumexcludedmassburning module¶

This module contains MEMB algorithms

fractalnetworks.maximumexcludedmassburning.MEMB(G, lB, deterministic=True)[source]¶

Implements the Maximal Excluded Mass Burning (MEMB) algorithm as introduced by (Song, Gallos, et al., 2007). Note that this method only works for odd values of lB. For even lB, MEMB(lB) = MEMB(lB-1).

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network the algorithm is to be applied to.

  • lB (int) – The diameter of the boxes used to cover the network.

  • deterministic (bool, optional) – Decides the tie breaking rule. If False, choose fom nodes with equal excluded mass uniformly at random. If True, choose the first lexicographically.

Returns:

A list of nodes assigned to be centres under the MEMB algorithm.

Return type:

(list)

fractalnetworks.maximumexcludedmassburning.accelerated_MEMB(G, lB)[source]¶

Implements the Maximal Excluded Mass Burning (MEMB) algorithm (Song, Gallos, et al., 2007), with time improvements. Rather than calculating the excluded mass for all nodes at each stage,

calculate the excluded mass of the node with the next highest excluded mass in the previous stage.

Then reject all nodes with excluded mass in the previous stage less than this value. Repeat until only one node is left, and this becomes the next p. Note that this method only works for odd values of lB. This method is always deterministic (ties are broken lexicographically). For even lB, MEMB(lB) = MEMB(lB-1).

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network the algorithm is to be applied to.

  • lB (int) – The diameter of the boxes used to cover the network.

Returns:

A list of nodes assigned to be centres under the MEMB algorithm.

Return type:

(list)

fractalnetworks.maximumexcludedmassburning.distance_based_MEMB(G, lB)[source]¶

Implements the Maximal Excluded Mass Burning (MEMB) algorithm (Song, Gallos, et al., 2007), with time improvements. First finds the distance between all pairs of nodes and then calculates the excluded mass as the number of nodes

within a distance of rB = (lB-1)/2

Note that this method only works for odd values of lB. For even lB, MEMB(lB) = MEMB(lB-1).

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network the algorithm is to be applied to.

  • lB (int) – The diameter of the boxes used to cover the network.

Returns:

A list of nodes assigned to be centres under the MEMB algorithm.

Return type:

(list)

fractalnetworks.maximumexcludedmassburning.distance_based_MEMB_all_lB(G, lB_min=3)[source]¶
Calculates the centres for each lB up to the diameter of the network

by first calculating the shortest path distance between every pair of nodes in the network.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • lB_min (int, optional) – The minimum diameter of the boxes for the box covering. Default is 3.

Returns:

Tuple containing two lists.

The first is a list of all box diameters lB, and the second is a list of all numbers of boxes NB.

Return type:

(tuple)

fractalnetworks.maximumexcludedmassburning.find_next_centre(G, covered, rB, ordered_list)[source]¶

Find the node with the next highest excluded mass to be the next centre, as in the accelerated MEMB algorithm.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • covered (list) – A list of indices for the covered nodes in the network at the current stage.

  • rB (int) – The radius of boxes to be found.

  • ordered_list (list) – A list of tuples containing the nodes of the network and their most recently updated excluded mass, in decreasing order of excluded mass.

Returns:

Tuple containing a list and a tuple.

The list is the updated version of the ordered list. The tuple contains the index of the new centre p and its excluded mass.

Return type:

(tuple)

fractalnetworks.maximumexcludedmassburning.time_improved_MEMB(G, lB, deterministic=True)[source]¶

Implements the Maximal Excluded Mass Burning (MEMB) algorithm (Song, Gallos, et al., 2007), with time improvements. In this version, the nodes within a radius r_B of a node are only found once, and then updated when covered. Note that this method only works for odd values of lB. For even lB, MEMB(lB) = MEMB(lB-1).

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network the algorithm is to be applied to.

  • lB (int) – The diameter of the boxes used to cover the network.

  • deterministic (bool, optional) – Decides the tie breaking rule. If False, choose fom nodes with equal excluded mass uniformly at random. If True, choose the first lexicographically.

Returns:

A list of nodes assigned to be centres under the MEMB algorithm.

Return type:

(list)

fractalnetworks.maximumexcludedmassburning.update_excluded_mass(G, covered, node, rB)[source]¶

Update the excluded mass for a given node with the list of covered nodes, per the accelerated MEMB algorithm.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • covered (list) – A list of the nodes which are currently covered in the network.

  • node (igraph.Vertex) – The node whose excluded mass is to be updated.

  • rB (int) – The radius of the boxes for the box covering.

Returns:

The updated excluded mass for the given node.

Return type:

(int)

fractalnetworks.modelanalysis module¶

This module analyses the properties of known network models.

fractalnetworks.modelanalysis.HADG_no_of_edges(m, n)[source]¶

Finds the number of edges in an n-th generation HADG network with parameter m (Kuang et al., 2013).

Parameters:

  • m (int) – The number of offspring added at each stage, as defined by the HADG model (Kuang et al., 2013).

  • n (int) – The number of iterations to perform of the HADG generative process (Kuang et al., 2013).

Returns:

The number of edges in the network.

Return type:

(int)

fractalnetworks.modelanalysis.HADG_no_of_nodes(m, n)[source]¶

Finds the number of nodes in an n-th generation HADG network with parameter m (Kuang et al., 2013).

Parameters:

  • m (int) – The number of offspring added at each stage, as defined by the HADG model (Kuang et al., 2013).

  • n (int) – The number of iterations to perform of the HADG generative process (Kuang et al., 2013).

Returns:

The number of nodes in the network.

Return type:

N (int)

fractalnetworks.modelanalysis.SHM_no_of_edges(m, n)[source]¶

Finds the number of edges in an n-th generation SHM network with parameter m.

Parameters:

  • n (int) – The number of iterations to perform of the SHM generative process (Song, Havlin, and Makse, 2006).

(int)

fractalnetworks.modelanalysis.SHM_p0_degree_dist(m, n)[source]¶

Calculates the degree distribution of an SHM network with p=0

Parameters:

  • m (int) – The parameter m in the SHM network model to test (Song, Havlin, and Makse, 2006).

  • n (int) – The parameter N in the SHM network model (Song, Havlin, and Makse, 2006).

Returns:

Tuple containing two lists, specifically:

a list of the degrees in the network; a list of probabilities of a node having a given degree.

Return type:

(tuple)

fractalnetworks.modelanalysis.SHM_p0_degree_prob(m, d, n)[source]¶

Calculates the probability P(d) for a given degree d in an SHM network with parameters m, n and p=0.

Parameters:

  • m (int) – The parameter m in the SHM network model (Song, Havlin, and Makse, 2006).

  • d (int) – The degree to find the probability density P(d) for.

  • n (int) – The parameter N in the SHM network model (Song, Havlin, and Makse, 2006).

Returns:

The probability P(d) from the degree distribution.

Return type:

(float)

fractalnetworks.modelanalysis.SHM_p1_degree_dist(m, n)[source]¶

Calculates the degree distribution of an SHM network with p=1

Parameters:

  • m (int) – The parameter m in the SHM network model to test (Song, Havlin, and Makse, 2006)

  • n (int) – The parameter n in the SHM network model (Song, Havlin, and Makse, 2006)

Returns:

A tuple containing two lists, specifically:

a list of the degrees in the network; and a list of probabilities of a node having a given degree, where degree_dist[i] is P(degrees[i])

Return type:

(tuple)

  • n (int) – The parameter n in the HADG network model (Kuang et al., 2013).

fractalnetworks.modelanalysis.check_SHM_p0_lambda(m_max, n, plot=False, verbose=False)[source]¶

Verifies that the analytical result for lambda agrees with the empirical result (Song, Havlin, and Makse, 2006).

Parameters:

  • m_max (int) – The maximum value of parameter m in the SHM network model to test.

  • n (int) – The parameter n in the SHM network model.

  • plot (bool, optional) – If True, plots a comparison of the results. Default is False.

  • verbose (bool, optional) – If True, prints results to terminal. Default is False.

Returns:

Tuple containing two lists, specifically:

a list of the values of lambda found by fitting a power law distribution to empirical data; and a list of the values of lambda determined by the analytical argument.

fractalnetworks.networkproperties.hub_distance_distribution(G, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, degrees=None)[source]¶

Find the distribution of distances between hubs.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • hubs (:obj:`list `, optional) – A list of hubs in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the function finds the hubs.

  • hub_method (function, optional) – Specifies the method used to find hubs. Default is identify_hubs.

  • degrees (list, optional) –

    A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication.

    Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

Returns:

A dictionary with distances as keys and

the probability of two hubs being separated by that distance as the values.

Return type:

distance_distributions (dict)

fractalnetworks.networkproperties.mean_hub_distance(G, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, normalised=False, degrees=None)[source]¶

Finds the mean distance between hubs. The normalised mean distance is the mean distance between hubs over

the mean distance between any pair of nodes in the network.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • hubs (list, optional) – A list of hubs in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the function finds the hubs.

  • hub_method (function, optional) – Specifies the method used to identify hubs. Default is identify_hubs.

  • normalised (bool, optional) – If true, the distances are normalised over the average distance. Default is False.

  • degrees (list, optional) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, passing this parameter prevents duplication. Default is None, in which case the distribution is calculated.

Returns:

Tuple containing a float and list, specifically:

the mean distance between pairs of hubs in the network; and a list of distances between pairs of hubs.

Return type:

(tuple)

fractalnetworks.networkproperties.summarise_graph(G, skip_diam=False, skip_aspl=False)[source]¶

Summarises the key attributes of a given network.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • skip_diam (bool, optional) – If True, then do not calculate the diameter of the graph. This is recommended for large graphs. The default is False.

  • skip_aspl (bool, optional) – If True, then do not calculate the average shortest path length. This is recommended for large graphs. The default is False.

fractalnetworks.utilities.find_best_exp_fit(x, y, A_min=0, A_max=10000, c_min=0, c_max=12.5, linspace_N=100)[source]¶

Finds the best exponential fit of the form y = Ae^{-cx} according to the sum of squares deviation.

Parameters:

  • x (list) – The values of x in the distribution.

  • y (list) – The values of y in the distribution.

  • A_min (int, optional) – The minimum value of A to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 0.

  • A_max (int, optional) – The maximum value of A to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 100.

  • c_min (int, optional) – The minimum value of c to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 0.

  • c_max (int, optional) – The maximum value of c to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 2.

  • linspace_N (int, optional) – The number of values of A and c to be checked in the respective ranges. Default is 100.

Returns:

A tuple containing a tuple and float, specifically:

the coefficients A and c from the best exponential approximation; and the sum of squares regression of this approximation.

Return type:

(tuple)

fractalnetworks.utilities.find_best_fit_iteratively(x, y, method, linspace_N=100, A_min=0, A_max=10000, c_min=0, c_max=12.5, iter_num=4)[source]¶

Finds the best fit according to a given model by iteratively reducing the range of values checked for A and c.

Parameters:

  • x (list) – The values of x in the distribution.

  • y (list) – The values of y in the distribution.

  • method (func) – A function which finds the best fit to the given distribution according to a given model.

  • linspace_N (int, optional) – The number of values of A and c to be checked in the respective ranges. Default is 100.

  • A_min (int, optional) – The minimum value of A to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 0.

  • A_max (int, optional) – The maximum value of A to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 10000.

  • c_min (int, optional) – The minimum value of c to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 0.

  • c_max (int, optional) – The maximum value of c to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 12.5.

  • iter_num (int, optional) – The number of iterations to complete.

Returns:

A tuple containing a tuple and a float, specifically:

the coefficients A and c from the best approximation; and the sum of squares regression of this approximation.

Return type:

(tuple)

fractalnetworks.utilities.find_best_fractal_fit(x, y, A_min=0, A_max=10000, c_min=0, c_max=12.5, linspace_N=100)[source]¶

Finds the best exponential fit according to the sum of squares deviation of the form y = Ax^{-c}

Parameters:

  • x (list) – The values of x in the distribution.

  • y (list) – The values of y in the distribution.

  • A_min (int, optional) – The minimum value of A to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 0.

  • A_max (int, optional) – The maximum value of A to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 10000.

  • c_min (int, optional) – The minimum value of c to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 0.

  • c_max (int, optional) – The maximum value of c to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 12.5.

  • linspace_N (int, optional) – The number of values of A and c to be checked in the respective ranges. Default is 100.

Returns:

The coefficients A and c from the best power law approximation. best_score (float) : The sum of squares regression of this approximation.

Return type:

best_fit (tuple)

fractalnetworks.utilities.find_best_linear_fit(x, y, A_min=0, A_max=100, c_min=0, c_max=10, linspace_N=101)[source]¶

Finds the best exponential fit according to the sum of squares deviation of the form y = Ax^{-c}

Parameters:

  • x (list) – The values of x in the distribution.

  • y (list) – The values of y in the distribution.

  • A_min (int, optional) – The minimum value of A to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 0.

  • A_max (int, optional) – The maximum value of A to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 10000.

  • c_min (int, optional) – The minimum value of c to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 0.

  • c_max (int, optional) – The maximum value of c to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 12.5.

  • linspace_N (int, optional) – The number of values of A and c to be checked in the respective ranges. Default is 100.

Returns:

A tuple containing a tuple and float, specifically:

the coefficients A and c from the best power law approximation; and the sum of squares regression of this approximation.

Return type:

(tuple)

fractalnetworks.utilities.find_best_power_law_fit(x, y, A_min=0, A_max=10000, c_min=0, c_max=12.5, linspace_N=100)[source]¶

Finds the best exponential fit according to the sum of squares deviation of the form y = Ax^{-c}

Parameters:

  • x (list) – The values of x in the distribution.

  • y (list) – The values of y in the distribution.

  • A_min (int, optional) – The minimum value of A to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 0.

  • A_max (int, optional) – The maximum value of A to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 10000.

  • c_min (int, optional) – The minimum value of c to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 0.

  • c_max (int, optional) – The maximum value of c to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 12.5.

  • linspace_N (int, optional) – The number of values of A and c to be checked in the respective ranges. Default is 100.

Returns:

A tuple containing a tuple and float, specifically:

a tuple of the coefficients A and c from the best power law approximation; and the sum of squares regression of this approximation.

Return type:

(tuple)

fractalnetworks.utilities.plot_best_fit_comparison(lB, NB, exp_A, exp_c, exp_score, frac_A, frac_c, frac_score)[source]¶

Plots a comparison of the best power law (fractal) and exponential (non-fractal) fit for a given distribution.

Parameters:

  • lB (list) – List of the values of lB.

  • NB (list) – List of the corresponding values of NB.

  • exp_A (float) – The optimal value of A according to the exponential fit.

  • exp_c (float) – The optimal value of c according to the exponential fit.

  • exp_score (float) – The sum of squares regression for the exponential best fit.

  • frac_A (float) – The optimal value of A according to the power law fit.

  • frac_c (float) – The optimal value of c according to the power law fit.

  • frac_score (float) – The sum of squares regression for the power law best fit.

fractalnetworks.utilities.plot_best_fit_comparison_by_logarithm(lB, NB, exp_A, exp_c, exp_score, frac_A, frac_c, frac_score)[source]¶

Plots a comparison of the best power law (fractal) and exponential (non-fractal) fit for a given distribution.

  • NB (list) – List of the corresponding values of NB.

  • exp_A (float) – The optimal value of A according to the exponential fit.

  • exp_c (float) – The optimal value of c according to the exponential fit.

  • exp_score (float) – The sum of squares regression for the exponential best fit.

  • frac_A (float) – The optimal value of A according to the power law fit.

  • frac_c (float) – The optimal value of c according to the power law fit.

  • frac_score (float) – The sum of squares regression for the power law best fit.

fractalnetworks.utilities.plot_lB_NB(lB, NB)[source]¶

Plots the distribution of the optimal number of boxes NB against the diameter of the boxes lB.

Parameters:

  • lB (list) – List of the values of lB.

  • NB (list) – List of the corresponding values of NB.

fractalnetworks.utilities.plot_loglog_lB_NB(lB, NB)[source]¶

Plots the distribution of the optimal number of boxes NB against the diameter of the boxes lB on a log-log scale.

Parameters:

  • lB (list) – List of the values of lB.

  • NB (list) – List of the corresponding values of NB.

fractalnetworks.utilities.plot_scatter_graph(fractal_attribute, non_fractal_attribute, fractal_Ns, non_fractal_Ns, y_label, save_path=None, plot=True)[source]¶

Plots a comparison of the properties of fractal and non-fractal networks on a scatter graph.

Parameters:

  • fractal_attribute (list) – A list of an attribute of fractal networks.

  • non_fractal_attribute (list) – A list of an attribute of non-fractal networks.

  • fractal_Ns (list) – A list of fractal network orders.

  • non_fractal_Ns (list) – A list of non-fractal network orders.

  • y_label (str) – Label for the y-axis, i.e. the attribute being plotted.

  • save_path (str, optional) – The file path to save the figure to, if given. Default is None.

  • plot (bool, optional) – If True, display the network. Default is True.

fractalnetworks.utilities.preprocess_network(filepath, save=True)[source]¶

Preprocesses a network to simplify and take the giant component.

Parameters:

  • filepath (str) – The filepath of the network .gml file.

  • save (bool, optional) – If True, saves the processed network to a new gml file.

Returns:

The processed network.

Return type:

(igraph.Graph)

fractalnetworks.utilities.read_graph(filepath)[source]¶

Checks the filetype and calls the correct function to read the graph. For any file not in .gml format, an additional .gml file is created. Supports .mtx, .txt, .edge (.EDGE) and .gml filetypes.

Parameters:

filepath (str) – Path for the network file.

Returns:

The network from the file stored as a graph.

Return type:

(igraph.Graph)

fractalnetworks.utilities.read_lB_NB_from_csv(filepath)[source]¶

Reads the lB-NB distribution from a csv file.

Parameters:

filepath (str) – The filepath to the .csv file.

Returns:

A tuple of two lists.

The first contains all box diameters lB, the second contains the corresponding values of NB.

Return type:

(tuple)

fractalnetworks.utilities.read_mtx_graph_format(filepath)[source]¶

Reads graphs stored in the .mtx file format. Use with, for example, graphs from www.networkrepository.com. Some files may need to be edited to make sure that scipy.io can read them. Files should have a header starting with %%MatrixMarket and a single line with the number of values in each column.

Parameters:

filepath (str) – Filepath to .mtx file

Returns:

Network read from file.

Return type:

(networkx.Graph)

fractalnetworks.utilities.sum_of_squares_error(y, est_y)[source]¶

Finds the value SSR for the sum of squares regression method using a true and model distribution.

Parameters:

  • y (list) – The true or measured distribution.

  • est_y (list) – The model distribution to be compared.

Returns:

The sum of squares regression

Return type:

(float)

fractalnetworks.utilities.swap_edges_at_random(G, number_edges_to_swap)[source]¶

Swaps edge of a given network at random, to find an uncorrelated network with the same degree distribution. Removes two randomly chosen edges (a,b) and (c,d) and replaces them with edges (a,d) and (c,b).

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The original network.

  • number_edges_to_swap (int) – The number of edges to swap.

Returns:

The new, uncorrelated network with the same degree distribution as G.

Return type:

(igraph.Graph)

Module contents¶

Import fractalnetworks to use the fractal network toolkit. This module contains functions for the analysis of fractal networks.

Fractal Networks
